importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the recall of Colombia's ambassador to the U.S., marking a significant escalation in diplomatic tensions between Colombia and the United States.
The previous recall of Colombia's ambassador in July, indicating a recurring pattern of diplomatic friction between the two nations over drug policy and political threats.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately following President Trump's accusations and the U.S. missile attacks on alleged drug-smuggling vessels, during which diplomatic relations deteriorated rapidly.

keyTakeAways: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, marking a significant escalation in diplomatic relations.
This is the second time this year that the Colombian ambassador has been recalled, following a previous incident in July when the U.S. summoned its ambassador in Bogotá.

The diplomatic rift stems from disagreements over drug trafficking, U.S. attacks on vessels allegedly involved in drug smuggling, and allegations that the U.S. supported efforts to remove Colombian President Gustavo Petro from power.
President Donald Trump accused Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and threatened to cut large-scale financial subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods.

The U.S. has deployed warships in the Caribbean and launched missile attacks on seven vessels, resulting in at least 30 deaths, with Petro claiming some victims were Colombian nationals and accusing the U.S. of 'murder'.
A Colombian citizen aboard the most recent vessel attacked was returned alive to Colombia, highlighting the human cost and diplomatic sensitivity of the situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, marking a sharp escalation in diplomatic tensions. This follows a previous incident in July when the U.S. summoned its ambassador in Bogotá. The conflict centers on allegations that the U.S. supported a plot to remove President Gustavo Petro from power, and on U.S. missile attacks on seven vessels suspected of drug trafficking, resulting in at least 30 deaths, some of whom may have been Colombian nationals. President Donald Trump has accused Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods. The actions have intensified regional and global concerns about drug policy, state sovereignty, and the use of military force in international affairs.
title: Colombian ambassador to US recalled to Bogotá for consultations, embassy says
